entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
19/03 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks – or: what we think is worth sharing – every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the forty-seventh edition:

Laura:
  • So you think you know Vim? – Is it a quiz? Is it a game?
  • Gutter Color – A Sublime Text 3 Package
  • Gittip – Sustainable Crowdfunding for your favorite people
Alex:
  • Feature Flipper for Rails – Flip lets you declare and manage feature flags
  • Testing at Airbnb – “[…]The bar to writing tests should be, ‘so low you can trip over it.’[…]”
  • Github Pull Request Triage tool – Its goal is to try to get an overview of what needs to happen next to open pull requests.

entry.title: vienna.rb Anniversary - a Short Flashback
entry.content:
I’m sitting at sektor5, our long time host for our monthly user group meeting, and am trying to remember the last year. Yes, it’s really been a year already. Over a year if you consider that it begun with us (Andy, Floor and me) complaining about the non-existant interaction between ruby users in Vienna. Shortly after that, it got too fast for me, and I just tried to hang tight and not get lost on the ride …

From “somebody should do something” to “Hey, we got a first sponsor and host!”, we did a lot of things, like setting up a web page, finding that first sponsor and a place to meet, and, mainly, getting the word out. Well, I wasn’t too involved with everything except setting up the basis for the web page and then providing the occasional content and talk.

It’s been great to stand at the sidelines and see the community grow. Within a year, we managed to get from zero to more than 200 (214 actually!) rubyists. I heard a LOT of interesting talks, and learned a bit from every pick the others provided (and also by myself searching for a good pick and getting lost in the internets).

But I guess it’s the time to really, really give a big THANK YOU to Floor. It must have been hard at the beginning – getting programmers and the like to submit stuff at a regular basis is worse than herding cats. I just saw the reaction. For Viennese standards, we had people basically breaking down the doors to get in. I have to admit that at the very first meeting I succumbed to a bad cold, but already at the second meeting we had more people than I dared to dream of. And that has been the work of one of the busiest women I’ve ever met.

Also, Andy has been invaluable in getting people to behave, having talks lined up and starting off the evening. And together we managed to do last minute stuff, rush people from here to there and generally make it look like no one ever broke a sweat (but we did occasionally, really).

How much has happened this year! Ruby 1.8.7 was discontinued, Ruby matured from 2.0.0-p0 to 2.1.1, Ruby and Rails had many vulnerabilities fixed, security awareness shifted dramatically …

We also had turbulent times: we attended meeting at Rubyslava & PyVo in Bratislava to meet our new friends who definitely helped us set up the whole thing and really helped us with their presence. Shout out to you guys!

Additionally, a lot of other events were sprouting off the success of the group: Rails Girls events all over Europe, PyLadies meetings, coding dojos, etc.

For me it was a lot of fun, a lot of new things that happend all around us, and then the saddest thing happened: Floor and Andy decided to move on, so Berlin got two great people, organizers and ‘just do it’ guys. And the next team took over — Laura, Ben and Alex (with me again on the sidelines). A surprisingly huge load of work awaited, but we eventually mastered it. Not least because we have a steady host with sektor5, which brings the necessary work every month down a lot.

So, I’m going to close that now because the first people have already arrived, and we are going to be busy soon – preparing cupcakes, stickers, t shirts and whatever talks and other things still have to finish.

Thanks to all and to a successful next year! (I almost wrote ‘beer’ now. Cheers!).

PS: Also thanks to our today’s sponsor, platogo!

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
12/03 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks – or: what we think is worth sharing – every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the forty-sixth edition:

Laura:
  • Scout Realtime – Realtime server metrics in your browser
  • Curator’s Code – Keep the rabbit hole of the internet open by honoring discovery
  • Jurassic Systems – Just. Epic.
Alex:
  • Command Line Cheat Sheet – Cheat sheet explains the essential tasks on the command line.
  • gitsh – gitsh provides you with a dedicated shell just for your Git commands.
  • rails-mrap-seed – For those who need to go fast on Rails.
Ben:
  • simple animated screen captures – create little gifs from your screen
  • Visualizing Rails Issues – Awesome use of D3.js by @joannecheng at Kod.io Linz 2014
  • Aviation is stuck in the 60s, a reflection on MH 370
Tony:
  • How to review a merge commit – Invaluable skill in teams
  • Rails and OmniAuth – an example application
  • RailsApps Build and Learn – main page of the above example

  • Rails Concern – Understanding how ‘Concern’ works will help you better understand how Ruby’s ‘Module’ works.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
08/01 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks – or: what we think is worth sharing – every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the thirty-seventh edition:

Laura:
  • Projects – A list of practical projects to be solved in any language.
  • The Mathematical Reality of Reality – An interview with cosmologist Max Tegmark.
  • Cruncher – An implementation of Bret Victor’s Scrubbing Calculator.
Alex:
  • Spacegray – A set of minimal Sublime Text 2/3 themes.
  • Sublime Ruby Debugger – Debugger plugin for interactive ruby and RoR debugging on Sublime Text.
  • CDN for Rails – Setting up a cloudfront CDN for Rails.
Ben:
  • Connection Pooling – Setting ActiveRecord’s connection pool size on Heroku with Puma or Sidekiq
  • FFmpeg Security – FFmpeg and a thousand fixes
Tony
  • Martin Fowler: Branch by Abstraction – Make a large-scale change while releasing regularily.
  • Mocks are “breaking encapsulation” – Grzegorz Gałęzowski disagrees with his notions (and I agree with him).
  • Extreme Programming, a Reflection – Uncle Bob Martin gives a lot of nostalgia a reality check. We’ve come far!

Alex:
  • SVG Drawing Animation – Line drawing animation with illustration fade-in

  • The Lost Art of C Structure Packing

  • –
Alex:
  • Drawing on canvas – Exploring canvas drawing techniques
  • Text-only UI sketches – Before sketching in that notebook, try writing out your UI first.
  • Sinatra Cookbook – Recipes for the Ruby framework
Ben:
  • TracePoint – An Introduction to TracePoint in Ruby 2.0
  • OpenEmu – play all your childhood games! howto build
  • –

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
04/12 Picks!!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks – or: what we think is worth sharing – every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the thirty-second edition:

Andy:

  • Nerdbot 2.0 Based on Lita – Because robots are awesome.
Floor:
  • Arduino-Bootcamp – You REALLY want to attend the last Arduino-Bootcamp of the year, at Hotel Karolinenhof in Vienna, on December 7th.
  • List.js – Search, sort, and filter your HTML tables, lists, and more!
  • 24 Pull Requests – Giving back little gifts of code for Christmas.
Laura:
  • ExplainShell – Match command-line arguments to their help text.
  • FishShell – Because the 90s are back.
  • Mathematica – Mathematica now free for the Raspberry Pi.
Alex:
  • Free Programming Books – About like everything.
  • Which HTML color are you? – Why does HTML think “chucknorris” is a color?
  • Mature Optimization Handbook – Performance measurement and optimization.
Ben:
  • list of computer technology code names – Ever ran out of names for you projects or physical devices? pick a code name!
  • Blue Shell – friendly command-line matchers for shell scripting in ruby using RSpec.
  • How Github (no longer) Works.
